chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: Use this online help to find out more about configuring your automatic network connection by using the Network Auto-Magic (NWAM) graphical user interface (GUI). Links within the application take you to pages that provide more detailed information. You can also navigate through this help by using links that appear within the text or by clicking the various topics in the side pane.

sect1.title: About the Network Auto-Magic Process
sect1.para: The NWAM service simplifies basic network configuration by automatically configuring and managing your wired and wireless networks. The NWAM service addresses basic Ethernet and wireless configurations and enables you to perform various networking tasks, such as connecting to your wired or wireless network at startup and configuring new wired or wireless networks. The NWAM service also simplifies more complex network configurations, such as system-wide network configuration. In addition, this feature displays informational messages about the current status of your network connection and the overall health of your network.
Other feature capabilities include:

listitem.para: Multiple concurrent network connections
Detection of hot-plug events
Network modifiers support, for example, virtual private network (VPN) client applications.

sect1.para: Network configuration is managed by storing desired property values in the form of profiles. The service determines which profile should be active at a given time, depending on the current network conditions, then activates that profile.

There are two primary profile types: the Network Profile, which specifies the configuration of individual network interfaces, and Locations, which specify system-wide network configuration. The individual components that make up the network profile are referred to as network connections. You can use this application to configure and manage both types of profiles.

chapter.title: About the Network Status Notification Icon
chapter.para: The Network Status notification icon is displayed in the desktop panel's notification area at all times. The icon is the primary method for viewing the status of your network and for interacting with automatic network configuration processes. The Network Status notification icon is also where informational messages appear. The icon menu enables quick access to essential network functionality.
The icon's appearance indicates the overall condition of your network.
The following table illustrates the individual icon elements that are displayed on the desktop, along with a description.

entry.para: Indicates all manually enabled connections that are in the active network profile are online and that the required number of connections in the active profile group (if such a group exists) are online.

listitem.para: One connection if the group is of the Exclusive priority type
One or more connections if the group is of the Shared priority type
All connections in the group if the group is of the All priority type

Note that at least one online connection is wireless.
Indicates one or more manually enabled or priority group connections are offline, such that the status is no longer All online. In this example, at least one wired connection is online.

The Network Status notification icon is also displayed as Partially online if a wireless connection is pending user input, for example choosing an available wireless network or providing a wireless network password.
Indicates the NWAM service is disabled or in maintenance mode.

chapter.para: If one wireless network connection is enabled, its current wireless signal strength is displayed. If multiple wireless network connections are enabled, their average signal strength is displayed.

listitem.para: To display a summary of the current network status in a tooltip, hover your mouse over the icon.

To configure network preferences, click the icon to open the Network Preferences dialog. This function is only enabled for user accounts that have been assigned the Network Autoconf Admin rights profile by a system administrator.
To display the menu for the notification icon, right-click the Network Status notification icon.

sect1.title: How Connection Names Are Displayed
sect1.para: When viewing information about your network, note that connection names are displayed with the format, interface-type (link-name):

listitem.para: interface-type is "Wired" or "Wireless".
link-name is the link's vanity name, for example net0.
If the vanity name has not been defined, link-name is the default device name.

sect1.title: Working With the Network Status Notification Icon Menu
sect1.para: To display the contents of this menu, right-click the Network Status notification icon.
The Network Status notification's icon menu is made up of the following five sections:

listitem.para: This section contains a submenu that lists each available network location (shown in the following table). The current location is indicated by a radio button indicator.

entry.para: Applies only to system-provided locations (Automatic and No Network). Indicates that the system determines when to activate these locations.
Can be manually activated or deactivated by using the Network Locations dialog or the Network Status notification icon.
Location is activated or deactivated automatically according to user-defined rules.

listitem.para: To activate a location other than the current location, choose the new location from the menu.

When the Switch locations automatically option is selected on the menu, you have no manual control over location changes. In this case, all of the locations in the submenu are unavailable (grayed-out), and the most appropriate System or Conditional location will be activated automatically in response to changes in the network environment.

When the Switch locations manually option is selected on the menu, you have full control over location changes. In this case, any location in the submenu can be activated by choosing it, regardless of its activation type. Any location you activate in this manner remains active until you either activate a different location or choose the Switch locations automatically menu option.

This submenu also includes a Network Locations menu item that opens the Network Locations dialog. See . The Network Locations menu item is only enabled for user accounts that have been assigned the Network Autoconf Admin rights profile by a system administrator.

This section contains a list of network connections in the current network profile. Enabled connections are indicated by a check mark. To manually enable or disable a connection, check or uncheck it in the menu.

note.para: Connections that belong to a priority group in the active network profile cannot be enabled or disabled manually, and are shown as unavailable (grayed-out) in the submenu. For more about priority groups, see .

listitem.para: This submenu also contains a Network Profile menu item that opens the Network Preferences dialog, where the network profile can be switched or edited. For more information, see . The Network Profile menu item is only enabled for user accounts that have been assigned the Network Autoconf Admin rights profile by a system administrator.
This section contains a combined list of available favorite wireless networks and all of the other currently available networks that are broadcasting their wireless network name.

Each available wireless network name is displayed, along with icons that represent its current signal strength and security type (open or secure). Any networks to which you are currently connected are indicated with a check mark.

If multiple wireless interfaces are enabled in the current network profile, each wireless network name appears on the submenu once per enabled wireless interface. A wireless link name is shown in parentheses after each network name, to enable you to view and control which wireless interface is connected to which network.
If a wireless network is an ad-hoc (peer-to-peer) network, "ad-hoc" is shown in parentheses next to its network name.
If no networks are available, a single disabled No wireless networks detected menu item is displayed.

If all wireless connections are disabled in the active network profile, a single disabled menu item, No wireless connections enabled, is shown. If there are no wireless connections configured in any network profile, this section of the menu is hidden.
For more information about changing wireless networks, see .

This menu item is disabled if all wireless connections are disabled in the active network profile. If there are no wireless connections configured in any network profile, this menu item is hidden.

This menu item opens the Join Wireless Network dialog, when selected. Use this dialog to connect to a wireless network that is not broadcasting its network name. This menu item is disabled if all wireless connections are disabled in the active network profile. If there are no wireless connections configured in any network profile, this menu item is hidden. See for more information.

The icon for each entry indicates its activation type.

Network modifier is started and stopped manually by selection from menu or dialog

listitem.para: For more information, see .

note.para: Conditional network modifiers are unavailable (grayed-out) because you cannot start or stop a conditional network modifier from this submenu.

listitem.para: This submenu also includes a Network Modifier Preferences menu item that opens the Network Modifiers dialog. See . The Network Modifier Preferences menu item is only enabled for user accounts that have been assigned the Network Autoconf Admin rights profile by a system administrator.

Opens the Network Preferences dialog to enable you to configure your network connection. See . The Network Preferences menu item is only enabled for user accounts that have been assigned the Network Autoconf Admin rights profile by a system administrator.

chapter.title: Obtaining Information About Your Network's Status
chapter.para: There are several ways that you can check the status of your network connection. The quickest way to obtain essential information about your network is to look at the Network Status notification icon that is displayed in the desktop panel's notification area at all times. The icon's appearance indicates the overall status of enabled network connections.
Other ways that you can obtain information about the status of your network include the following:

listitem.para: Hovering your mouse over the Network Status notification icon to display a tooltip that provides information about the status of all enabled connections.
Viewing informational messages that are displayed in the desktop panel's notification area.

Right-clicking the Network Status notification icon to open its menu, where the currently available locations, wireless network names, network profiles, network modifiers, and network connections are shown.
Opening the Network Preferences dialog and switching to the Connection Status view.
This last method provides the most information about your currently enabled network connections.

sect1.title: To Show Details of Enabled Network Connections
sect1.para: Open the Network Preferences dialog, and select Connection Status from the drop-down list, if required. This method provides the most information about enabled network connections.
To open the Network Preferences dialog, do one of the following:

listitem.para: Choose System -> Administration -> Network from the Main Menubar on the desktop panel.
Right click the Network Status notification icon to open its menu, then select the Network Preferences menu item.

sect1.para: The list shows the status of all of the connections in the active network profile that are manually enabled and all those connections that are in the active priority group, if any. For more information, see .
For wired network connections, the IP address, connection speed and connection status are displayed.
For wireless network connections, the IP address, signal strength, connection speed connection status and security type are displayed.

To view the properties of a specific network connection, double-click the connection in the list. Alternately, you can open the Network Preferences dialog, and from the Show drop-down list that is located at the top of the dialog, select a connection.

chapter.title: Controlling Network Connections
chapter.para: By default, NWAM attempts to maintain a network connection at all times. If a wired network connection fails, an attempt is made to connect to one of your favorite wireless networks. If the attempt fails, other available wireless networks are tried, with your permission. For information about managing your favorite wireless networks, see .
You can also manually switch between wired and wireless networks, as required.

sect1.title: To Modify the Default Connection Priority
sect1.para: By default, all wired network connections take priority over all wireless network connections. That is, a wireless network connection is only attempted if a wired connection cannot be established. If more than one wireless network is available at the current location, you are prompted to select which network to join. This behavior is defined by the Automatic network profile, which is activated by default. To enforce a different behavior, you must create and activate a different network profile.

sect1.title: To Switch From a Wired Network to a Wireless Network
sect1.para: If the Automatic network profile is active, disconnect any network cables from all enabled wired interfaces.

By default, if any of your favorite wireless networks are available, an attempt will be made to join them in the order in which they appear in the favorites list. Otherwise, the Wireless Chooser dialog is displayed. In this dialog you can select which network to join.

note.para: You can change the way wireless networks are joined on the Wireless tab of the Connection Properties view. See .

sect1.para: If a network profile other than the Automatic network profile is active, the method that you use to switch to a wireless network depends on the definition of that network profile.
Choose from one of the following methods:

listitem.para: Use the Connections submenu of the Network Status notification icon to disable the wired connection and then enable a wireless connection. Note that this method is only possible if both connections have the Manual activation type.
Edit the active network profile to enable the wired connection and disable other connections, as required.

sect1.para: When the wireless connection is established, a notification message is displayed.
For more information, see .

sect1.title: To Switch From a Wireless Network to a Wired Network
sect1.para: If the Automatic network profile is active, plug a network cable into an available wired interface.
If a network profile other than the Automatic network profile is active, the method that you use to switch to a wired network depends on the definition of that network profile.
Choose from one of the following methods:

listitem.para: Use the Connections submenu of the Networks Status notification icon to disable the wireless connection and then enable a wired connection. Note that this method is only possible if both connections have the Manual activation type.
Edit the active network profile to enable the wired connection and disable the wireless connection.
When the wired connection is established, a notification message is displayed.

sect1.para: For more information, see .

sect1.title: To Switch From One Wireless Network to Another Wireless Network
sect1.para: If you want to join a wireless network other than the one to which you are currently connected:

listitem.para: Right-click the Network Status notification icon to access its menu.
Select the wireless network of your choice.
If the network is secure, you might be prompted for a password.

sect1.para: When the wireless connection is established, a notification message is displayed.

sect1.title: To Switch From One Wired Network Connection to Another Wired Network Connection
sect1.para: If you are using the Automatic network profile, it is not possible to choose which wired connection is active at any given time. The most appropriate connection is automatically chosen.
If a network profile other than the Automatic network profile is active, the method that you use to switch to a wired network depends on the definition of that network profile.
Choose from one of the following methods:

listitem.para: Use the Connections submenu of the Networks Status panel notification icon to enable and disable wired connections, as required. Note that this method is only possible if both connections have the Manual activation type.
Edit the active network profile to enable the required wired connection and disable the other wired connection, as required.

sect1.para: When the wired connection is established, a notification message is displayed.
For more information, see .

chapter.title: About Joining Wireless Networks
chapter.para: By default, when any wireless network connections are enabled, NWAM attempts to connect to any available network in the favorites list, without asking, in the order in which the connections are listed. If no favorite networks are available, the Wireless Chooser dialog opens. In this dialog you can choose which wireless network to join. See .

You can also modify the way in which wireless connections are attempted in the Wireless tab of the Network Preferences dialog's Connection Properties view. See . If required, you can manually connect to a different wireless network by accessing the Network Status notification icon right-click menu. See .

sect1.title: Joining a Wireless Network
sect1.para: By default, NWAM attempts to join the most appropriate wireless network without further intervention.
To manually connect to a different wireless network, you can do one of the following:

listitem.para: Select an available wireless network from the Network Status notification icon's right-click menu.
Select “Join unlisted wireless network” from the Network Status notification's icon menu.
An unlisted wireless network is one that has been configured so that it does not broadcast its network name, yet is still available to join.
Select an available wireless network from the Wireless Chooser dialog. The dialog is displayed automatically, when required. See .

sect1.para: If you need to provide more information to complete the connection, the Join Wireless Network dialog opens.
In the dialog, enter the following information:

listitem.para: The name of the wireless network that you want to connect to. This information is pre-filled, unless you are joining an unlisted network.

A drop-down list of all the currently supported security protocols. If the network is broadcasting its network name, the security type is preselected when the dialog opens or when the network name is provided. The password field varies, depending on the security protocol that is selected.
None – No password is required to join the specified network.
WEP (Wired Equivalence Privacy) – A password is required to join the specified network. A password must have either 5 or 13 ASCII characters or 10 or 26 hexadecimal digits (0-9, A-F).

A Key Index field is also displayed. This value is only used if a 5- or 13-character ASCII password is provided. Possible values are 1, 2, 3 or 4. If the wireless network administrator has not specified which value to use, leave the default setting, which is 1.
WPA-PSK (Wi-Fi Protected Access Pre-Shared Key, also known as WPA Personal) – A password is required to join the specified network. The password can be between 8 and 63 ASCII characters.
Check this option to see passwords displayed in plain text as you type. If unchecked, passwords will be masked as you type.
To automatically add the new network to your list of favorites, check this box.

An expandable section that displays the Known BSSIDs list. This is a list of the MAC addresses of access points that are associated with this wireless network's ESSID. This information, which is optional, enables the NWAM process to distinguish different wireless networks that have the same network name. You can edit the Known BSSIDs list, adding or removing items. See .

sect1.para: The OK button is disabled until a network name has been provided.

sect1.title: Working With the Wireless Chooser Dialog
sect1.para: The Wireless Chooser is a dialog that displays the wireless networks that are currently available and enables you to connect to one of them.
The Wireless Chooser dialog opens when any of the following events occur:

listitem.para: A wireless connection is attempted, but your favorite wireless networks list is empty.
No favorite networks have been found, and the Show available networks preference has been checked on the Wireless tab of the Connection Properties view in the Network Preferences dialog.
You click a panel notification message that says "Click this message to view other available networks".

sect1.para: Wireless networks are listed in descending order, according to signal strength. To update the list of available networks and their signal strengths, click the Refresh button.

To join the selected network immediately, click Connect. If you have not joined this network before, or if you have configured your preferences so that confirmation is required, the Join Wireless Network dialog opens. Enter or confirm the password and any other security credentials that are required.

Clicking Join Unlisted enables you to join a network that is not broadcasting its network name. After connecting to any such network, the network is displayed in the menu and in the list of favorite networks. If the network was not added to the list of favorites when you initially connected, it will disappear from the favorites list after you disconnect or end your session.

sect1.title: Working With Favorite Networks
sect1.para: By default, when you join a wireless network for the first time, a check box labeled, Add to List of Favorite Networks on Successful Connection, is displayed in the Join Wireless Network dialog.

listitem.para: To add the network to your list of favorites, if the connection is successful, check this box. If you do not want the network to be added to your list of favorites, uncheck the box. Note that the box is checked by default.

To add a network that is not currently available, or not currently broadcasting its network name to your favorites list, go to the Wireless tab of the Connection Properties view, then click the Add button. To add the network, you will need to know its network name, security type and security key.
To add unlisted or unavailable networks, remove networks, or edit networks in your favorites list, go to the Wireless tab of the Connection Properties view. See .

chapter.title: About the Network Preferences Dialog
chapter.para: The Network Preferences dialog is where you can configure individual network connections and view the current state of each network connection. The window provides access to various views that you can switch to by using the drop-down list that is located at the top of the dialog.
You can open the dialog three ways:

listitem.para: By selecting System > Administration > Network from the Main Menubar on the desktop panel
By clicking the Network Status notification icon
By selecting the Network Preferences menu item from the Network Status notification's icon menu

note.para: The Network Preferences dialog is only available to user accounts that have been assigned the Network Autoconf Admin rights profile by a system administrator.

chapter.para: At the top of the Network Preferences dialog is a drop-down list that is labeled, Show. This list enables you to switch between the Connection Status view, the Network Profile view, and the Connection Properties view for every network connection in each network profile.

sect1.title: Connection Status View
sect1.para: The Connection Status view displays information about each enabled network connection in the active network profile with the Manual activation type and each connection (enabled or disabled) in the active priority group. The Enabled Connections section lists all of the enabled connections, in the same order that they are listed in the Network Profile view.
For each connection, the following information is shown:

listitem.para: Type of connection (wired or wireless)
Link name
Current status (connected, connecting, or disconnected)
IPv4 and IPv6 addresses, if assigned
Information about whether addresses were obtained through DHCP (IPv4), DHCPv6 (IPv6), or Autconf (IPv6)
Signal strength (for wireless connections only)

sect1.para: A security icon that is displayed on the right side of the connection indicates whether the network is secured or unsecured. Note that this icon is only for wireless connections.

note.para: When you are in this view, you cannot change the order in which connections are attempted. To change the order in which connections are attempted, you will need to modify and activate a new network profile in the Network Profile view. For more information, see .

para.emphasis: The current status includes the following possible states:

listitem.para: A wired interface is attempting to connect, but is not yet connected.
A wired interface is connected.
A wireless interface is attempting to connect to the network with the given ESSID. A secure or open icon indicates whether the network is open or insecure.
A wireless interface is connected to the network, with the given ESSID. The secure or open icon indicates whether the network is open or insecure.
Wired or wireless interface is enabled, but not functional, or is unable to contact a DHCP server or gateway.
Wired interface is enabled, but the cable is unplugged.
Wired or wireless interface is enabled, but the connection could not be established.

sect1.para: To switch to the properties view of a particular connection, double-click the connection.
Other information that you can view or change in the Connection Status view include the following:

listitem.para: Displays the name of the active network profile.
Displays the active network location.
To open the Network Locations dialog, click Locations.
Lists any network modifiers that are currently running. For example, if you were running the Cisco VPN application, the words, “CiscoVPN active”, would be displayed.
To open the Network Modifiers dialog, click Modifiers. In this dialog, you can configure, start, and stop network modifiers.

sect1.para: For more information, see .

sect1.title: Network Profile View
sect1.para: This view enables you to configure network profiles. A network profile controls which network connections are enabled or disabled when that network profile is active. The default network profile is called Automatic. You can create additional network profiles, as required.
For more information, see .

sect1.title: Connection Properties View
sect1.para: To switch to the Connection Properties view for a specified network connection, select the connection name from the Show drop-down list or double-click the connection name while in either the Connection Status or the Network Profile view. A tabbed view appears, enabling you to view or edit the interface's properties.

listitem.para: The first tab for all connection types is the IP Address tab. Both IPv4 and IPv6 addresses can be configured on this tab.
A Wireless tab is also displayed, if the selected connection is wireless. Here, you can configure the list of Favorite networks, and choose how the wireless interface connects to available networks.

sect1.para: For more information, see .

chapter.title: Managing Network Profiles
chapter.para: A network profile specifies which network interfaces can be enabled or disabled at any given time. Using network profiles can be helpful in situations where you have more than one network interface available. For example, most modern laptop brands have both a wired and a wireless interface. Depending on your physical location, and your work environment, you might want to use only one of those interfaces and disable the other interface for security or other reasons.

The default network profile is called Automatic. The Automatic network profile first attempts to activate one wired connection. If the attempt fails, it then attempts to activate one wireless connection. You cannot edit the Automatic network profile. However, you can create multiple custom network profiles, as needed, each with their own behavior.

sect1.title: Viewing Available Network Profiles
sect1.para: Network profile information can be viewed in the Network profile view of the Network Preferences dialog.
To display this view, select Network Profile in the drop-down list that is located at the top of the Network Preferences dialog.

The Network Profiles list displays the name of each available network profile. The currently active profile is shown with a radio button indicator. By default, there is one profile, Automatic, that you can activate but not edit or delete. However, you can create multiple additional network profiles. Network profiles that are manually created can be activated, edited, or deleted, as needed.
Below the Network Profiles list is a summary of the profile that is selected. To view the selected profile in full or edit the profile, click the Edit button.

note.para: The selected profile might be different than the active profile.

sect1.title: To Switch From One Network Profile to Another Network Profile

listitem.para: Open the Network Profile view of the Network Preferences dialog.
Select the radio button next to the network profile that you want to activate.
To switch network profiles, click OK or click Cancel to close the dialog without switching profiles.

sect1.title: To Add or Remove a Network Profile
sect1.para: To create or edit a network profile, select Network Profile from the drop-down list that is located at the top of the Network Preferences dialog.

listitem.para: To create a new network profile, click the Add button, then type the name of the new profile.
To duplicate an existing network profile, select the profile in the list, click the Duplicate button, then type the name of the new profile.
To remove a network profile, select the profile in the list, then click the Remove button.

note.para: You cannot remove the Automatic network profile.

sect1.para: For more information about editing a profile that you have added or duplicated, see .

chapter.title: Editing Network Profiles
chapter.para: When you manually add a new network profile or duplicate an existing network profile, you must edit the new profile to specify those network connections that are enabled and disabled by the new profile.

note.para: You can edit and remove a manually created network profile. However, you cannot edit or remove the Automatic network profile.

sect1.title: Opening the Edit Network Profile Dialog
sect1.para: To edit a network profile, select the profile in the Network Profile view of the Network Preferences dialog, then click the Edit button.

The list of network profiles consists of a minimum of two top level group descriptions. For example, the Automatic profile, which is shown in the preceding figure, contains four group descriptions that are explained in more detail in the following sections.

note.para: The Automatic network profile cannot be changed or deleted. Any time the Automatic network profile is selected in the Edit Network Profile dialog, all of the profile editing buttons and drop-down lists are disabled.

listitem.para: This group is always present in a network profile, at the top of the list. The group contains network connections that are always enabled when the network profile is active. In the Automatic network profile, there are no such connections, so "None" is shown.

para.emphasis: Then enable any one of these connections:

listitem.para: This is a priority group that is comprised of connections. There may be zero, one, or more priority groups in a network profile. In the Automatic network profile, this group contains all of the available wired network connections.

para.emphasis: Else enable any one of these connections:

listitem.para: This is another priority group. These groups are listed in priority order, so this group has a lower priority than the group that is listed above it. In the Automatic network profile, this group contains all of the available wireless network connections.

This group is always present in a network profile and appears at the bottom of the list. The group contains network connections that are always disabled when the network profile is active. In the Automatic network profile, there are no such connections, so "None" is shown.

sect1.para: For more information, see .
The first line of text for each network connection in the network profile displays its interface type and interface name. The second line displays its IP address and MAC address.

sect1.title: To Always Enable or Always Disable Connections
sect1.para: A network connection in the "always enabled" group is always enabled when the selected network profile is active.
To move a network connection to the "always enabled" group, first select the connection, then do one of the following:

listitem.para: Click the Enable button.
Click the Up button until the connection moves to the “always enabled” group.

sect1.para: A network connection in the "always disabled" group is always disabled when the selected network profile is active.
To move a network connection to the "always disabled" group, first select the connection, then do one of the following:

listitem.para: Click the Disable button.
Click the Down button until the connection moves into the "always disabled" group.

sect1.para: For more information, see .

sect1.title: To Add, Edit, or Delete Priority Groups
sect1.para: You can create a network profile that treats one or more network interfaces as a group. If one or more of the interfaces in the highest priority group cannot be enabled, according to the group's priority type, then the group with the next highest priority is considered.
The following table describes the three different priority groups that are available.

entry.para: One connection in the group is enabled, and all the other connections are disabled. As long as at least one connection in the group is enabled (not necessarily the same one all the time), no attempt is made to enable connections in any of the lower priority groups.

All of the connections in the group that can be enabled are enabled. As long as at least one connection in the group remains enabled, no attempt is made to enable connections in any of the lower priority groups.

All of the connections in the group are enabled. If any of the connections are lost, all of the connections in the group are disabled. As long as all of the connections remain enabled, no attempt is made to enable connections in any of the lower priority groups.

sect1.para: For example, the default Automatic network profile contains two exclusive priority groups. The higher priority group contains all of the wired network connections. The lower priority group contains all of the wireless network connections.

listitem.para: In the Edit Network Profile dialog, select one or more network connections to include in the priority group.
The New Group button is enabled when one or more network connections are selected or when the always enabled or the always disabled group description is selected.
To create a new priority group comprised of selected network connections, click the New Group button.
The new group, with the type Exclusive, is created. Note that this new group will have a lower priority than any of the existing priority groups.

para.emphasis: To Edit the Contents of a Priority Group:

listitem.para: To move a selected network connection in or out of a priority group, click the Up or Down button.

The Up button is enabled when any network connection that is not in the “always enabled” group is selected. The Down button is enabled when any network connection that is not in the always disabled group is selected.
To move a selected network connection out of its current group to a group with a higher or lower priority, which might be a priority group or the always enabled group, click the Up or Down button.
To move a selected network connection out of a priority group, which might be a priority group, or the always enabled or always disabled group, click Up or Down button.
Alternately, you can drag and drop network connections in or out of priority groups.
When the last network connection has been moved out of a priority group, the group no longer exists, and it is then removed from the list.

para.emphasis: To Change the Priority Mode of a Priority Group:

listitem.para: To change the priority mode of a priority group, select its top-level group description or any of the connections that it contains. The Selected group drop-down list is displayed, along with the priority mode of the group that you selected.
To change the selected group's priority mode, choose from one of the following values in the drop-down list:
Exactly one connection is enabled: One connection in the group is enabled and all of the other connections are disabled. This value corresponds to the Exclusive priority type.
One or more connections may be enabled: All of the connections in the group that can be enabled are enabled. This value corresponds to the Shared priority type.
All connections must be enabled: All of the connections in the group are enabled. This value corresponds to the All priority type.

para.emphasis: To Increase or Decrease the Priority of a Group:

listitem.para: To increase a group's priority, select its group description, then click the Up button.
The Up button is disabled if the selected group already has the highest priority in the network profile.
To decrease a group's priority, select its group description, then click the Down button.
The Down button is disabled if the selected group already has the lowest priority in the network profile.
Select its group description.
The label of the New Group button changes to Remove Group.
To remove the priority group, click Remove Group.
The priority group is removed from the list and no longer exists.
Alternatively, you can delete a group by moving all of its connections into other groups.

sect1.title: To Add or Remove Connections

listitem.para: Open the Edit Connections dialog by clicking the Connections button. The Connections button is enabled for all network profiles except the Automatic profile.
The list displays all of the connections that are currently available in the Automatic network profile.
To include a connection in the selected network profile, place a check mark by the connection.
To remove a connection from the network profile, remove the check mark.

note.para: One connection must be checked at all times. It is not possible to uncheck a connection if it is currently the only checked connection in the network profile.

chapter.title: Configuring Network Connection Properties
chapter.para: Connection properties are configured in the Properties view of the Network Preferences dialog. This view enables you to choose how the IP address for a specific network interface is obtained. For wireless interfaces, this view also enables you to choose how and when wireless connections are automatically attempted. To display the network interface, select it from the Show drop-down list that is located at the top of the dialog.

After selecting a network interface, a tabbed view is shown, enabling you to edit the connection's properties. For all connection types, the first tab is the IP Address tab. In this tab you can configure IPv4 and IPv6 addresses. For wireless connections, a Wireless tab is also available. In this tab you can maintain a list of favorite wireless networks and choose the way a wireless interface connects to available wireless networks.

sect1.title: To Set Up IPv4 Addresses
sect1.para: IPv4 addresses can be assigned automatically, manually, or both, or disabled for each network interface.
The controls that are shown vary dynamically, based on the selection that is made from the IPv4 IP drop-down list:

listitem.para: No IP address is assigned to this network connection.

An IP address and subnet mask are assigned automatically for this network connection by a DHCP server on your network. If a default route is also assigned automatically, it will be displayed as read-only in the Default Route field. If a default route is not assigned automatically, you can type its IP address in the Default Route field.
When this option is selected, you can specify a default route and one or more IP address and subnet mask pairs for the specified network connection. See .

When this option is selected, one IP address and subnet mask is assigned automatically for the specified network connection by a DHCP server on your network. If a default route is also assigned automatically, it will be displayed as read-only in the Default Route field. If a default route is not assigned automatically, you can type its IP address in the Default Route field. You can also specify one or more additional IP address and subnet mask pairs. See .

sect1.para: For the manually assigned IP addresses, you can type the IP address and subnet values separately using the format, w.x.y.z.

Alternatively, you can provide an IP address that uses the Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR) format (an IP address that is followed by a slash (/ ) and a decimal number that specifies the number of consecutive bits of the subnet mask). For example, the IP address, 192.168.0.0/22, represents the 1024 IPv4 addresses ranging from 192.168.0.0 to 192.168.3.255.

When switching between DHCP assigned, manually assigned, and multiple IP addresses, any data that you provided previously is stored, in case you switch back to that view later. This information is also remembered between sessions.

sect1.title: To Set Up IPv6 Addresses
sect1.para: IPv6 addresses can be assigned automatically or manually, or disabled for each network interface.
The controls that are shown vary dynamically, based on the selection that is made from the Current IPv6 setting drop-down list:

listitem.para: No IPv6 address is assigned to this network interface.

An IPv6 address is assigned automatically for this network connection by a router on your network. The router will choose whether a stateful (DHCPv6) or stateless (Autoconf) IPv6 address is assigned. If a default route is also assigned automatically, it will be displayed as read-only in the Default Route field. If a default route is not assigned automatically, you can type an IP address in the Default Route field.
When checked, in addition to the IPv6 address (or addresses) that may be assigned automatically by DHCP or autoconfiguration, you can specify a default route and one or more IPv6 addresses. See .

sect1.para: When switching between disabled, enabled, and static addresses, any data that you provided previously is stored, in case you switch back to that view later. This data is also remembered between sessions.

sect1.title: To Manage a List of Favorite Wireless Networks
sect1.para: You manage your list of favorite wireless networks on the Wireless tab of the Connection Properties view. The Wireless tab becomes available when a wireless network interface is selected from the Show drop-down list that is located at the top of the Network Preferences dialog.
For more information, see .
The four-column list displays your current favorite (or "bookmarked") networks, in the order in which any automatic connection will be attempted.

listitem.para: The first column displays signal strength and the network name, or the Extended Service Set Identifier (ESSID).
The second column displays the wireless channel.
The third column displays the maximum transfer speed.
The fourth column displays the level of security, with secure networks indicated by an icon.

para.emphasis: To set the order in which connections to favorite networks are attempted, follow these steps:

listitem.para: Open the Network Preferences dialog and switch to the Properties view for any wireless network connection.
To display a list of your favorite networks, click the Wireless tab.
To reorder the list, drag and drop the items to the new position or use the Up and Down buttons.

sect1.para: The Wireless tab includes the following additional options:

listitem.para: To add a wireless network to the list, click the Add button to open the Add Wireless Network dialog.
To edit a wireless network, click the Edit button to open the Edit Wireless Network dialog.
To delete the selected wireless network from the list, click the Remove button.

sect1.para: The Add Wireless Network and the Edit Wireless Network dialogs enable you to add or edit the same information as the Join Wireless Network dialog. For more information, see .

sect1.title: To Configure Wireless Connection Preferences
sect1.para: Wireless connection preferences are configured on the Wireless tab of the Connection Properties view. The Wireless tab becomes available when a wireless network interface is selected from the Show drop-down list that is located at the top of the Network Preferences dialog.
A drop-down list with the following options indicates how to proceed if no favorite networks are available when a wireless connection is attempted:

listitem.para: Show list of available networks: Opens the Wireless Chooser dialog, where you can select another other wireless network to join.
Do not connect: Prevents a connection to any other wireless network until new networks are detected or a different network profile or location is selected.

chapter.title: Working With Locations
chapter.para: A location is a profile that comprises certain elements of a network configuration, including name service and firewall settings, which are applied together when required. For example, a laptop user might set up one location profile for a home network and another location for an office network. Because locations do not necessarily correspond to a physical location, you might also set up two different locations for use in the same workplace. One location could be used when you are connected to the company intranet. The other location could be used when you are connected to the public Internet by using a wireless access point that is located in your office.
Locations can be activated manually or automatically, according to environmental conditions, such as the IP address that is obtained by a network connection.

sect1.title: About the Network Locations Dialog
sect1.para: The Network Locations dialog enables you to switch locations, edit location properties, create new locations, and remove locations.

To open the dialog, choose Network Locations from the Network Status notification icon's right-click menu. Or, from the Main Menubar on the desktop panel, choose System -> Administration -> Network Locations.

note.para: The Network Locations dialog is only available to user accounts that have been assigned the Network Autoconf Admin rights profile by a system administrator.

sect1.para: The Locations list is similar to the list on the Network Status notification's icon menu. Each available location, with an icon that represents its activation type, is listed.
The following table describes the location activation types.

entry.para: Applies only to system-provided locations (Automatic and No Network). Indicates that the system determines when to activate these locations.
Can be manually activated or deactivated by using the Network Locations dialog or the Network Status notification icon.
Location is activated or deactivated automatically according to user-defined rules.

sect1.para: The activation type of the selected location is also displayed in the Selected location drop-down list. The active location is represented by a selected radio button that is displayed in the first column of the list.

sect1.title: To Change a Location's Activation Mode

listitem.para: Choose Network Locations from the desktop notification icon's right-click menu. Or, from the Main Menubar on the desktop panel, choose System > Administration > Network Locations.
To change the activation mode of a location, select the location in the list, then select the new activation mode the Selected location drop-down list.
Note that when a system location is selected, the drop-down list shows Activated by system, and both the drop-down list and the Edit Rules button are disabled.
When a Manual or a Conditional location is selected, the drop-down list options are as follows:
Manual activation only: This location is only enabled when it is manually selected. When this option is selected, the Edit Rules button is disabled.
Activated by rules: This location is automatically selected under certain network conditions. When this option is selected, the Edit Rules button is enabled.
(Optional) To set rules for how and when a location is activated, click the Edit Rules button. For more information, see .

sect1.title: To Switch From One Location to Another Location
sect1.para: From the Network Status notification icon's Location submenu, choose the location that you want to activate.

listitem.para: If the Switch Locations Automatically option is selected on the Locations submenu, you cannot manually choose a location to activate. The most appropriate System or Conditional location will be activated automatically at any given time, according to changes in the network environment.
If the Switch Locations Manually option is selected on the Location submenu, you can activate any available location, regardless of its activation type. That location remains active indefinitely.

sect1.para: Alternately, you can open the Network Locations dialog from the desktop panel applet's right-click menu. Or, from the Main Menubar on the desktop panel, choose System -> Administration -> Network Locations. To switch to a different location, select the radio button of that location, then click OK.

listitem.para: If the Switch Locations Automatically radio button is selected in the Network Locations dialog, you cannot manually choose a location to activate. The most appropriate System or Conditional location will be activated automatically at any given time, according to changes in the network environment.

If the Switch Locations Manually radio button is selected in the Network Locations dialog, you can activate any available location, regardless of its activation type. That location remains active indefinitely.

sect1.title: Editing Locations
sect1.para: To edit a location, open the Network Locations dialog by choosing Network Locations from the Network Status notification icon's right-click menu. Or, from the Main Menubar on the desktop panel, choose System -> Preferences -> Locations.
To edit the properties of a specified location, select the location in the list, then click Edit.
Alternatively, you can double-click the location in the list.
The Edit Location dialog opens, with the following two tabs available:

listitem.para: Enables you to configure name services in the specified location.
Enables you to select configuration files to be used by IP Filter and IPsec features, when the specified location is active.

sect1.para: To display the information to be edited, select the appropriate tab.

sect1.title: To Add a Location
sect1.para: New locations are added in the Network Locations dialog.

listitem.para: Open the dialog by choosing Network Locations from the Network Status notification icon's right-click menu. Or, from the Main Menubar on the desktop panel, choose System -> Administration -> Network Locations.
To add a new location with default settings, click the Add button.
A new location that has the Manual activation type, is created with a temporary name. The name is selected so that you can type a new name immediately.
Type the name of the new location, then press Enter to save your changes.
To activate the location, click the radio button next to the location and then click OK.

sect1.title: To Remove a Location
sect1.para: Locations are removed in the Network Locations dialog.

listitem.para: Open the dialog by choosing Network Locations from the Network Status notification icon's right-click menu. Or, from the Main Menubar on the desktop panel, choose System -> Administration -> Network Locations.
Select the location to remove, then click the Remove button.
The Remove button is disabled when a system location (Automatic or No Network) is selected. These locations cannot be deleted.
To save your changes, click OK.

sect1.title: To Rename a Location
sect1.para: Locations are renamed in the Network Locations dialog.

note.para: You can only rename a location immediately after you have added it. After you click the OK button to confirm the addition of the location and close the Network Locations dialog, the location name is fixed and cannot be edited.

listitem.para: Open the dialog by choosing Network Locations from the Network Status notification icon's right-click menu. Or, from the Main Menubar on the desktop panel, choose System -> Administration -> Network Locations.
Select the location to rename, then click the Rename button.
The location name is replaced by an in-place editable text field in the list.
Type the new location name in this field, then press Enter.
To revert to the previous location name, press Esc.

sect1.title: To Duplicate a Location
sect1.para: Locations are duplicated in the Network Locations dialog.

listitem.para: Open the dialog by choosing Network Locations from the Network Status notification icon's right-click menu. Or, from the Main Menubar on the desktop panel, choose System -> Administration -> Network Locations.
Select the location, then click the Duplicate button.
A new location is created with a temporary name.
Type a new location name, then press Enter.
To cancel your changes, press Esc.
To activate the location, select the radio button next to the location, then click OK.

sect1.title: To Configure Name Services For a Location
sect1.para: The name services that are used when a location is active are specified on the Name Services tab of the Edit Location dialog.
To specify which name services should be configured for this location, check one or more of the DNS, NIS, LDAP or Files check boxes.

listitem.para: Can be configured manually or through DHCP, by selecting the Manual or DHCP radio button. When configured manually, one or more name servers must be specified in the Servers text field that is provided. A domain name and search domain may optionally be specified.

Can be configured manually or through DHCP, by selecting the appropriate radio button. When configured manually, a domain name must be specified in the Default Domain text field. One or more name servers may also be specified in the Servers text field.
Can only be configured manually. A domain name must be specified in the Default Domain text field, and one or more name servers must be specified in the Servers text field.
No further configuration options are available.

sect1.para: Where required, multiple servers or search domains can be separated by spaces or commas.

note.para: Separate domain names cannot be specified for the NIS and LDAP protocols. Both protocols must use the same default domain name.

sect1.para: The Custom nsswitch file button enables you to choose the name service configuration file that is to be used for this location.

When a single name service is selected for this location, you can either use the default name service configuration file, or specify a custom configuration file. To specify a custom configuration file, click the Custom nsswitch file button to open a file chooser dialog. To revert to the default name service configuration file, click the Use Default button. The full pathname of the default configuration file that is associated with the selected name service is displayed below the Use Default button.

When multiple name services are selected for this location, you must always choose a custom configuration file by clicking the Custom nsswitch file button, as there is no default configuration file that can be used.

note.para: Editing the values in this dialog does not result in any changes being written to the nsswitch configuration file. Therefore, you might need to manually edit the selected file to achieve the desired behavior.

sect1.title: To Configure Security Features for a Location
sect1.para: The Security tab of the Edit Location dialog enables you to select configuration files that are used by the IPfilter and IPsec security features when a specified location is active.
The behavior of the check boxes and file chooser buttons are as follows:

listitem.para: When you check a box – The corresponding file chooser button is enabled. If no file name is currently associated with the feature, a file selection dialog immediately opens. Here, you can choose a configuration file. Otherwise, the file name that was previously shown is used until you click the file chooser button.

When you uncheck a box – The corresponding file chooser button is disabled. The file name that is shown iis no longer associated with that feature when the location is active. The last-used file name remains visible in the disabled control and is remembered between sessions.

chapter.title: Configuring Network Modifiers
chapter.para: The Network Modifiers dialog enables you to configure and monitor applications that temporarily change the behavior of enabled network connections. One example of a network modifier would be a virtual private network (VPN) client application.

note.para: Before you can manage network modifiers by using the Network Modifiers dialog, you must manually install the network modifier application or service, then complete any initial setup, such as the installation of a certificate or shared secret.

chapter.para: A network modifier can be started and stopped manually, as required. A network modifier can also be started automatically, according to user-defined rules. To be managed by using this dialog, a network modifier must either be implemented as a command-line tool, or as an SMF service.

sect1.title: About the Network Modifiers Dialog
sect1.para: Use this dialog to add or remove, start and stop, and edit network modifiers.
Open the dialog using one of the following methods:

listitem.para: Click the Modifiers button in the Connection Status view of the Network Preferences dialog.
Right-click the Network Status notification icon, then select the Network Modifier Preferences menu item.

note.para: The Network Modifiers dialog is only available to user accounts that have been assigned the Network Autoconf Admin rights profile by a system administrator.

sect1.para: The main section of the dialog is a three-column list that displays the following information for each network modifier:

listitem.para: Activation state (Manual or Conditional)
User-defined name, for example, “Cisco VPN”
Current status, “Running” or “Stopped”

sect1.para: The Start/Stop according to rules check box is checked if the selected network modifier has a Conditional activation type, and unchecked if the activation type is Manual. To change the activation type, toggle the check box.

sect1.title: To Add a Command-Line Network Modifier

listitem.para: Open the VPN Applications dialog by using one of the following methods:
Click the Modifiers button in the Connection Status view of the Network Preferences dialog.
Right-click the Network Status notification icon, then select the Network Modifier Preferences menu item.
Click the Add button.
Type the name of the new network modifier.
Do one of the following:
To add a new entry that will have the Manual activation type, press Enter or Tab.

The two Manage modifiers radio buttons are enabled. The first of these, Command Line Applications, is selected by default. The Start and Stop command fields, and the two Browse buttons, are also enabled.
To cancel your changes, press Esc.
Type the command that starts the network modifier into the Start Command field.
Alternately, you can use the Browse button to open a file chooser dialog, where you can select the command to use.
The Start button remains disabled for the network modifier until a valid command has been typed into this field.
Type the command that stops the network modifier into the Stop Command field.
Alternately, you can use the Browse button to open a file chooser dialog, where you can select the command to use.
The Stop button remains disabled for the network modifier until a valid command has been typed into this field.
To add this application, click OK.

sect1.title: To Add a Network Modifier Service

listitem.para: Open the Network Modifiers dialog by using one of the following methods:
Click the Modifiers button in the Connection Status view of the Network Preferences dialog.
Right-click the Network Status notification icon, then select the Network Modifier Preferences menu item.
Click the Add button.
Type the name of the new network modifier.
Do one of the following:
Press Enter or Tab to add the new entry that will have the Manual activation type, by default.

note.para: You can rename a network modifier immediately after you have added it. After you press Enter or Tab to add the new entry and close the Network Modifiers dialog, the network modifier name is fixed and cannot be edited.

listitem.para: To cancel your changes, press Esc.
Select the Manage modifier using an SMF Service radio button.
When the Manage modifier using an SMF Service radio button is selected, the Service FMRI field is enabled.
Type the FMRI of the SMF service using any of the following formats:
By specifying the absolute path:
By specifying a path that is relative to the local system:
By specifying only the service identifier, with the string prefixes implied:
The Start and Stop buttons remain disabled for the network modifier until a valid FMRI has been typed in this field.
To add the service, click OK.

sect1.title: To Start and Stop a Network Modifier
sect1.para: You can start or stop a network modifier that has a Manual activation type by selecting Start application-name or Stop application-name from the Network Status notification icon's Network Modifiers submenu.
Alternatively, you can follow these steps:

listitem.para: Open the Network Modifiers dialog using one of the following methods:
Click the Modifiers button in the Connection Status view of the Network Preferences dialog.
Right-click the Network Status notification icon, then select the Network Modifier Preferences menu item.
To start a network modifier manually, select the application in the list, then click Start.

para.emphasis: To manually stop a network modifier:

listitem.para: Select the application in the list, then click Stop.
The Stop button is enabled only for applications that are currently running.

para.emphasis: To automatically start and stop a network modifier:

listitem.para: Set the application's activation type to Conditional. For more information, see .

sect1.title: To Set Rules for a Network Modifier
sect1.para: You can set rules that enable a network modifier to start and stop automatically.

listitem.para: Open the Network Modifiers dialog in one of the following ways:
Click the Modifiers button in the Connection Status view of the Network Preferences dialog.
Right-click the Network Status notification icon, then select the Network Modifier Preferences.. menu item.
Select the network modifier for which you want to set the rule, then check the Start/Stop according to rules check box.
Click the Edit Rules button to open the Edit Rules dialog.
Specify the conditions under which the selected network modifier should be started.

note.para: Whenever the conditions are no longer met, the network modifier will be stopped.

listitem.para: For more information about editing rules, see .

sect1.title: To Remove a Network Modifier

listitem.para: Open the Network Modifiers dialog in one of the following ways:
Click the Modifiers button in the Connection Status view of the Network Preferences dialog.
Right-click the Network Status notification icon, then select the Network Modifier Preferences menu item.
To remove a network modifier from the list, first select it, then click the Remove button.
If the selected network modifier is running, the Remove button is disabled. Stop the network modifier before attempting to remove it.

chapter.title: Reference
chapter.para: This section includes additional instructions on the following topics:

sect1.title: Working With Editable Tables
sect1.para: The Network Preferences and the Network Locations dialogs include tables whose contents can be edited, for example when adding multiple IP addresses in the Connection Properties view of the Network Preferences dialog.
When editing tables, follow these general instructions:
If the contents of a table's cells are not fully visible, an ellipsis is displayed. To display any hidden content in a tooltip, hover your mouse over the table cell.

To add a new row, place your cursor in any empty cell, then click the Add button. Alternately, you can add a new row by double-clicking any cell within an empty row. Depending on the type of information that is being added, the first cell in a new row might be a text field, a combo box, or a menu.

para.emphasis: To complete the entry for the new cell:

listitem.para: Type some text into the cell, or select a menu item from the drop-down list or menu. Then, press Return or Tab to move the keyboard focus to the next cell. When you have finished typing information in the last cell of a row, pressing Return or Tab moves the focus to the first cell of the next row.
To move to the next cell in a row, press the Tab key. To move to the previous cell in a row, press the Shift+Tab keys.
If you type any text before pressing the Tab key, the text remains in the cell. Note that keyboard focus wraps between rows, but not between the first and the last cell within a table.

para.emphasis: To cancel an entry for the entire row:

listitem.para: To cancel or clear the information you have typed in a cell, press Esc.

sect1.para: To edit a cell:

listitem.para: Double-click the cell you want to edit.
Type the new information in the cell or select a different item from the popup menu or the drop-down list.
To cancel any pending changes, press Esc.

sect1.para: There are two ways to remove a row:

listitem.para: Select the row by clicking any cell in the row, then click the Remove button.
Multiple rows can be selected by holding Ctrl or Shift keys while selecting the rows.
Click the Remove button while any cell in the row is being edited.

sect1.title: Working With the Rules Dialog
sect1.para: The Rules dialog is accessed from the Network Locations and the Network Modifiers dialogs.
The Rules dialog enables you to specify the conditions under which certain actions should be performed, such as when a particular location should become active.
You create a rule by specifying one or more conditions. You then specify whether all of those conditions need to be met, or only one of the conditions needs to be met, before the action is performed.

If you are creating a new rule, the dialog opens with one incomplete condition shown. To complete the condition, select the condition type from the drop-down list that shows, Select condition. All of the possible condition types are listed in the following table. Note that the availability of each condition type varies, depending on the action that is performed when the conditions are met.

entry.para: The specified network connection is (or is not) enabled and connected.
The specified network profile is currently active.
The IP address of any enabled connection matches (or does not match) the specified address, or falls (or does not fall) into the specified range of addresses.

note.para: IP address ranges are specified in CIDR format (w.x.y.z/n). For example, the IP address, 192.168.0.0/22, represents the 1024 IPv4 addresses ranging from 192.168.0.0 to 192.168.3.255.

entry.para: The domain name that is advertised to any enabled connection by a DHCP server matches (or does not match) the specific domain, or contains (or does not contain) the specified string.

The domain name that is currently assigned to the system, as returned by the domainname command, matches (or does not match) the specified domain, or contains (or does not contain) the specified string.
The active location matches (or does not match) the specified location.
The specified network modifier is (or is not) currently running.
Any enabled wireless interface is currently connected to a wireless network whose ESSID matches (or does not match) the specified network name, or contains (or does not contain) the specified string.
Any enabled wireless interface is currently connected to a wireless network whose BSSID matches (or does not match) the specified BSSID.

sect1.para: Having selected the condition type, do one of the following:

listitem.para: Complete the condition by choosing or typing the appropriate terms in the adjacent controls.

For example, to enter the condition "Wireless network name is OfficeNet", first select the condition type, Wireless network name. From the second drop-down list, select is, then type "OfficeNet" into the adjacent text field.

To add another condition, click the Add (+) button that is displayed next to any existing condition. To remove an existing condition, click the Remove (-) button that is displayed next to that condition.
If the action is to be performed when any one of the conditions is met, click the Match Any button. Use the Match All button, if all of the conditions must be met before the action is performed.
To discard any changes you made to the rules since opening the dialog, click the Revert button. The dialog remains open for further editing.
